questions.question: What should be included in a PR description?
options: What changed, why, how to test, and screenshots/examples (if UI changes)
questions.explanation: Every PR should include: (1) What changed? (brief summary), (2) Why? (context or motivation), (3) How to test? (steps for reviewers), and (4) Screenshots/Examples (if UI changes). This helps reviewers understand the context and purpose of your changes.

questions.question: What is the Pre-PR Checklist?
options: A list of things to do after creating a PR
A list of files to include in the PR
A checklist to complete before opening a PR: code works, tests pass, clean commit history, rebased on latest main, linting/formatting done, no debug code
Optional suggestions that don't need to be followed
questions.explanation: Before opening a PR, ensure: code works and compiles, tests pass, commit history is clean, branch is rebased on latest main, linting/formatting is done, and all debug code (console.logs, commented code) is removed.

questions.question: What is a good size for a PR?
options: Small enough to be reviewed in 15-30 minutes
As large as possible to include everything
questions.explanation: Small PRs are easier to review and understand. Aim for PRs that can be reviewed in 15-30 minutes. Keep PRs focused - one feature or fix per PR.

questions.question: What should you do before asking others to review your PR?
options: Wait for someone to notice it
Self-review first: look for typos, obvious bugs, and unclear code
questions.explanation: Self-review your own PR before asking others. Look for typos, obvious bugs, and unclear code. This helps catch issues before your teammates review it.

questions.question: When reviewing a PR, what should you check?
options: Understand the change, code works, tests included, code quality, no obvious bugs, documentation
questions.explanation: Review checklist includes: understand the change, code works and tests pass, tests are included for new functionality, code quality (clarity, naming, conventions), no obvious bugs, and documentation is clear.

questions.question: What is an important step in the review workflow that reviewers sometimes skip?
options: Testing the changes locally by checking out the branch
questions.explanation: Testing the changes locally is very important! Reviewers sometimes skip this step, but pulling down the branch locally and running the code helps catch issues that might not be obvious from just reading the code.

questions.question: What are the types of comments you can leave in a PR review?
options: Questions, suggestions, required changes, and praise
questions.explanation: Types of comments include: (1) Questions to clarify understanding, (2) Suggestions for improvements, (3) Required changes for issues that must be fixed, and (4) Praise to acknowledge good work.

questions.question: What's the difference between 'Approve', 'Request changes', and 'Comment'?
options: Approve = ready to merge, Request changes = issues need fixing, Comment = optional feedback
Approve = merge immediately, Request changes = optional, Comment = required
questions.explanation: Approve means the PR looks good and is ready to merge (after rebase if needed). Request changes means there are issues that need to be addressed before merging. Comment means you have feedback but it's not blocking (optional improvements).

questions.question: What should you do when giving feedback in a PR review?
options: Be constructive and kind, ask questions, suggest specific improvements, explain why, acknowledge good work, focus on code not person
questions.explanation: When giving feedback: be constructive and kind, ask questions if unclear, suggest specific improvements, explain why you're suggesting a change, acknowledge what's good about the code, and focus on the code not the person.

questions.question: When is it safe to use `--force-with-lease`?
options: Only on feature branches, never on main
questions.explanation: `--force-with-lease` is safe to use on feature branches after amending or rebasing. Never force push to `main` - it can overwrite important commits and cause problems for your team.

questions.question: When is a good time to commit?
options: When you've completed a logical piece of work, code compiles, and tests pass
Every 5 minutes to save your work
Only at the end of the day
When code is broken but you want to save it
questions.explanation: Commit when you've completed a logical piece of work (e.g., 'Add tests for login endpoint'), code compiles, and tests pass. Each commit should represent a working state that you'd be okay showing in a PR.

questions.question: What is rebase and why is it required before merging a PR?
options: Rebase is optional and not recommended
Rebase rewrites commit history by replaying your commits on top of the latest main, creating a clean linear history
questions.explanation: Rebase rewrites commit history by replaying your commits on top of the latest `main`. It creates a clean, linear history without merge commits. All PRs must be rebased before merging to ensure they're based on the latest code.

questions.question: What is the team fork structure in Phase 1?
options: Each team member has their own fork
Everyone works directly on the main repository
One team member forks the repo, all members are collaborators on that fork, everyone works from the same fork
questions.explanation: In Phase 1, one team member forks the starter repository, all team members are added as collaborators on that fork, and everyone clones and pushes to the same fork. This ensures all team members can see each other's work.

questions.question: What should you do if you have too many small 'save point' commits?
options: Delete the branch and start over
Use interactive rebase (`git rebase -i HEAD~N`) to squash them into logical commits
questions.explanation: Use interactive rebase to clean up your commit history. Change `pick` to `squash` for commits you want to combine. This creates a clean history that tells a good story and makes code reviews easier.

questions.question: What is the rule about committing directly to `main`?
options: Never commit directly to main - always create a feature branch first
You can commit directly to main if it's a small change
Main is for experimental code only
Only commit to main on weekends
questions.explanation: Never commit directly to `main`. Always create a feature branch for each feature/assignment. This keeps work isolated and makes code reviews easier before changes are merged.

questions.question: What command should you use to fix a mistake in your last commit?
options: `git commit --amend` - to update the last commit without creating a new one
questions.explanation: Use `git commit --amend` to update the last commit. This is useful when you realize the last commit has a bug or is incomplete. Use `--no-edit` to keep the same message, or `-m` to change it.

questions.question: What should you do if you realize your last commit has a bug?
options: Fix the bug, then use `git commit --amend` to update the last commit
Create a new commit to fix it
questions.explanation: If you realize the last commit has a bug: (1) Fix the bug, (2) Stage the changes with `git add`, (3) Use `git commit --amend` to update the last commit, (4) Force push if you've already pushed the branch.

questions.question: What should you do even if a PR is approved?
options: The author should still rebase onto latest `main` before merging
questions.explanation: Even if you approve a PR, the author should still rebase onto latest `main` before merging. This ensures the PR is based on the latest code and creates a clean, linear history.
